docs.lead_paragraph: It was only two years ago that Bob Dole went on ''The Larry King Show'' to discuss his prostate-cancer operation. During a commercial break, so the story goes, King leaned over to ask his old friend, confidentially, how he was dealing with the operation's grimmest side effect, impotence. Dole cheerfully informed the talk-show host that there was a new drug, Viagra, and miraculously, it had cured the problem. King asked Dole if he would discuss it on the air, and Dole said sure, why not? The world was about to become a very different place. Viagra would cycle through the expected paces of pop-culture acceptance with stunning speed. Leno and Letterman got an entire summer's worth of monologues off the subject. For a while the papers regularly pumped out clowning (and possibly true) stories about the drug -- there was Frank Bernardo, 70, who left his wife, declaring, ''It's time for me to be a stud again''; there was also Gen. Sani Abacha of Nigeria, who died in the midst of a Viagra-fueled encounter with two women in his magisterial bed.
docs.abstract: Jack Hitt article on impending wave of new drugs and devices for men and women designed to treat sexual dysfunction set to follow in Viagra's wake; notes drugs will also enhance sex for normally functioning people; sees medical approach to treating impotence growing out of cultural shift that spurred view of sex as lively part of good health; cartoon; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Judaism is a religion that has existed for more than 5,000 years. It has produced profound religious texts and countless interpretations of those texts. Christianity and Islam grew out of Judaism. Millions upon millions of religious and nonreligious people have been directly or indirectly affected by the teachings of Judaism. I never read an article about ultra-Orthodox Jews that begins to deal with that history. Usually the only mention of Orthdox Judaism is a statement that men say a prayer thanking God for not having created him a woman. In Leslie Cahmi's article ''The Ultra-Orthodox and Their Women'' [Feb. 13], about Amos Gitai's film ''Kadosh,'' that prayer is mentioned in the first paragraph. The intention of mentioning that prayer is to focus on how sexist Orthodox Jews are. Of course, their views on the roles of men and women are different from ours today. Why is there never a mention of the fact that Orthodox women also say a prayer every day? The prayer thanks God for making them who they are. There are separate but equally important roles and obligations for men and women. For society to function on its highest level, both are necessary. Men and women are not the same. Because of biology women have pregnancy and major child rearing responsibilities. They are relieved of many of the responsibilities that men are required to perform. It may not conform to contemporary views of the role of women, but it would give the uninformed reader a better understanding than your article, and countless others give. JERRY FREEDMAN Los Angeles
docs.abstract: Jerry Freedman letter says Leslie Cahmi's Feb 13 article on the film Kadosh gave a false and unfair account of the place of women in Orthodox Judaism

docs.lead_paragraph: The headline on an article regarding the permit granted to us for a clinic in Massapequa [''Planned Parenthood Gets Limited Permit,'' Feb. 6] implied that Planned Parenthood of Nassau County had agreed to restrict its activities at the health center. This is simply not true. Through his representatives, Supervisor John Venditto of the Town of Oyster Bay asked us to put into writing a statement that Planned Parenthood would never perform abortions at the Massapequa site, a request we refused. While I did inform Mr. Venditto in writing that at this time, Planned Parenthood has no plans to perform surgical abortions at this site, the permit we received from the Town of Oyster Bay places no restrictions on the kinds of services we can perform in Massapequa, now or in the future.

headline.main: Planned Parenthood Sees No Restriction at New Clinic

docs.lead_paragraph: American women will wait a while longer for the abortion-inducing pill RU-486. The Food and Drug Administration declared in 1996 that RU-486 was safe and effective for American women to use, saying it would approve the drug's sale as soon as it received some final information about manufacturing and labeling.

headline.main: National News Briefs; F.D.A. Says Questions Still Delay Abortion Pill

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Beautiful People'' ends in a flurry of rapid cuts, with a series of perfectly ordinary moments: a man reads a picture book to a child; a family sets out on vacation. There is a wedding party, a birthday party, and a raucous game of cards around a hospital bed. Jasmin Dizdar's camera hurtles through these scenes like a child in a toy store, grabbing at every detail as though it were a shiny, precious prize. The screen hums with the vital cacophony of daily life, and glows with the thick, bright colors of human emotion -- unspeakable pain, inexplicable loss, and sheer irrational pleasure at being alive. And then the whiplash motion abruptly stops, as though interrupted, and the last thing we see before the credits roll is a wedding band on the hand of one of the card players. The ring comes to us as a found image, but it is also a resonant symbol of one of the movie's main themes: the desire for connection.

headline.main: Struggling to Reconnect What Chaos Rips Apart

docs.abstract: A O Scott reviews movie Beautiful People, written and directed by Jasmin Dizdar; Charlotte Coleman and Charles Kay star; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The State Department of Health is investigating Medicaid billing practices at a Queens women's medical clinic that hired an obstetrician after he carved his initials into a patient's belly, department officials said yesterday. The clinic, Choices Women's Medical Center in Long Island City, employed the doctor, Allan Zarkin, as its medical director for two months after the September incident at Beth Israel Medical Center in which he performed a Caesarean section and sliced his initials into the patient, Dr. Liana Gedz.

headline.main: Medicaid Billing Is Checked At Women's Clinic in Queens

docs.abstract: New York State Department of Health is investigating Medicaid billing practices at Choices Women's Medical Center, Queens clinic that hired obstetrician, Dr Allan Zarkin, after he carved his initials into patient's belly (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On Sept. 7, when Liana Gedz was rolled into the operating room at Beth Israel Medical Center for a Caesarean section, life at the hospital's obstetrics and gynecology department seemed to be back on track at last. The unit, a target of the State Health Department following the death of a patient in 1997, was as busy as ever, delivering nearly 5,500 babies a year. A new department chairman, Dr. Daniel Saltzman, was widely viewed as raising the quality and accountability of his subordinates.

headline.main: At Beth Israel, Lapses in Care Mar Gains in Technology

docs.abstract: Article, noting case in which Dr Allan Zarkin carved in his initials in belly of patient, Dr Liana Gedz, after delivering baby by Caesarean section, contends that once again Beth Israel's obstetrics unit has spelled disaster for hospital that has busily promoted gains in medical technology; Zarkin's case has put obstetrics department under microscope of NYS Department of Health for second time in two years; hospital officials say that unlike case of Lisa Smart's death in 1997, where systematic failures were found, latest case does not reflect any institutional problems; Dr Daniel Saltzman, chairman of hospital's obstetrics department, comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pinched Nerves Q. What is a pinched nerve, and what is it pinched between? A. A pinched, compressed or entrapped nerve can be surrounded by swollen tissues or impinged upon by bony processes in many areas of the body, according to The American Academy of Family Physicians Family Health & Medical Guide (Word Publishing). The cause can be injury, disease or even pregnancy. The result is pain, numbness, tingling and weakness in the part of the body to which the nerve normally carries impulses.
docs.abstract: Answer to reader's query about 'pinched' nerve
